### A concrete success story – **Measles** | Item | Details | |------|---------| | **What the disease looked like before vaccination** | • In the United States, ≈ 500 – 600 measles deaths occurred each year in the 1950s and early‑1960s.
• In 1963, before the measles vaccine was introduced, there were **≈ 3–4 million cases** and **≈ 400–500 deaths** annually in the U.S. (CDC). | | **Vaccination program that changed that** | • **Measles‑containing vaccine (MCV)** – usually given as part of the MMR (Measles‑Mumps‑Rubella) combo.
• Recommended schedule in the U.S.: **first dose at 12‑15 months**, **second dose at 4‑6 years** (or earlier if there is an outbreak). | | **Impact after the vaccine** | • **1990s‑2000s:** U.S. measles cases fell to < 200 per year (≈ 30‑40 times fewer than pre‑vaccine era).
• **2020‑2023:** Only **≈ 30–50** confirmed cases each year, all linked to importations and limited secondary spread (CDC, 2024).
• Worldwide, global measles deaths dropped from **≈ 540 000 in 2000** to **≈ 140 000 in 2022** after the introduction of routine childhood vaccination (WHO, 2023). | | **How long does protection last?** | • **Two‑dose MMR** provides **≈ 97 %** effectiveness against measles after the first dose and **≈ 99 %** after the second dose (CDC, 2022).
• Immunity is considered **long‑lasting (decades)**; most people retain protective antibodies well into adulthood.
• **Breakthrough infections** are rare and usually mild; they occur mainly when the second dose is missed, when the vaccine was given before the child’s immune system could respond (e.g., maternal antibodies still present), or when the virus is circulating at very high intensity. | | **When boosters are needed (if at all)** | • In most high‑income countries, **no routine measles booster after the two childhood doses** is recommended.
